This Is Graham Hovey with another radio Letter from Italy and the date¬

In my previous Letter from Italy I tried to demonstrate how a cabinet
crisis begins in Italy and how the -President of the Republic takes the first
steps necessary to resolve much a crisis. If you heard that Letter you heard
the voice of Giuseppe Pella, as he announced his resignation as prime minis¬
ter. You heard President Luigi Einaudi, thanking Italian newsmen for keeping
the public informed about the development of the crisis. And, finally, you
heard Amintore Fanfanl tell the nation — through a Radio Italians microphone
— that President Einaudi had asked him to form a new government azkl that he
had accepted "with reserve."
That1 a about where we left Italy1 s January political crisis in that pre-
vlous letter. The ball had passed from President Einaudi to Signer Fanfanl.
And Fanfanl was about to begin the exhausting series of conferences with the
country's political leaders to discover whether he could command enough
support to form a government and end the crisis.
Let’s pick up the Fanfanl story at that point. You’ll recall that Fan-
fani had-accepted President Einaudi1 s assignment with the traditional
reserve" at about 12 noon on Tuesday. January 12. Almost everyone expected
that Fanfanl would go back to Einaudi1 s study at the oulrinal palace in three
days, four at the latest.
Italian politicians have a theory that a premier-designate should not
wait much longer than that before doing one of two things* either deciding
to go ahead with the attempt to form a government or informing the president
that the situation does not look promising and that he must be relieved of
the commission.
They say that pressures on a man in that position invariably mount as
time pasaasj that the prices exacted by individual politicians and political
parties for participation in the new government or support of it inevitably
go up if the premier-designate seems uncertain.
And the politicians and editorial writers also say that it’s lust bad
business to keep the country on the hook beyond that first 72 or 96 hours.
They say the people are apt to lose faith in their governmental system,
particularly in a nation such as Italy, where the present democratic system
is only eight years old.
well, Fanfanl didn’t go back to the ^lirinal® on Friday — and he didn’t
go back on Saturday, either. The fact la that he was having his troubles.
At one point during those days, according to a report circulating in Rome,
Fanfanl was almost at the point of giving up his attempt.
I won’t go into detail at the moment on the reasons for those Fanfanl
troubles. -They had something to do with that heterogenous character of
Fanfanl’s Christian Democratic party that was the subject of a previous Letter.
